title: Why Focus on Cervical Cancer
description: Learn the global, regional, and local impact of cervical cancer and why it matters.

sections.name: section-1-1
sections.title: Reasons to Focus on Cervical Cancer
sections.description: Why cervical cancer is a global health priority.

learningCards.name: section-1-1-card-1
learningCards.title: Global Impact of Cervical Cancer
learningCards.content:
Every year, around 266,000 women die from cervical cancer worldwide. This staggering number represents not just statistics, but real lives lost to a largely preventable disease.

Most of these deaths can be prevented through proper cervical cancer prevention and treatment programs. This highlights the critical importance of education, screening, and accessible healthcare.

learningCards.name: section-1-1-card-2
learningCards.title: HPV Connection
learningCards.content:
Almost all cervical cancer is caused by a long-lasting infection with certain harmful types of the human papillomavirus (HPV). Understanding this connection is key to prevention strategies.

The disease usually develops slowly over 10â€“20 years. This gives enough time to detect and treat it early, making regular screening incredibly valuable for prevention.

learningCards.name: section-1-1-card-3
learningCards.title: Early Detection Methods
learningCards.content:
There are low-cost tests that can find pre-cancer early. These screening methods are accessible and effective tools for preventing cervical cancer development.

HPV vaccines are now available. If given to girls before they become sexually active, a large portion of cervical cancer can be prevented. This represents a major breakthrough in prevention.

sections.name: section-1-2
sections.title: Epidemiology of Cervical Cancer
sections.description: Understanding the global and African burden of the disease.

learningCards.name: section-1-2-card-1
learningCards.title: Global Burden
learningCards.content:
Cervical cancer is the 4th most common cancer in women, with 660,000 new cases and 350,000 deaths in 2022.
New cases of cervical cancer are estimated to rise to 760,100 cases, with 411,000 deaths by 2030.
Around 94% of these deaths happened in low- and middle-income countries, showing a major gap in access to care.
The highest rates of cervical cancer and deaths are seen in Sub-Saharan Africa, Central America, and South-East Asia.
These differences are mainly due to inequality in access to HPV vaccines, cervical cancer screening and proper treatment

learningCards.name: section-1-2-card-2
learningCards.title: Africa's Cervical Cancer Burden
learningCards.content:
Africa bears a disproportionate cervical cancer burden. 
Africa has the highest rates of both new and cervical cancer cases and deaths from the disease. 
In Africa, 34 out of every 100,000 women are diagnosed with cervical cancer and 23 out of every 100,000 women die from cervical cancer every year. 

These disparities are mainly due to: 
Limited access to healthcare 
Low vaccination rates against HPV 
Few women getting screening or treated early.

learningCards.name: section-1-2-card-3
learningCards.title: Ghana's Cervical Cancer Burden
learningCards.content:
The country has a high incidence rate of cervical cancer, about 18.3 cases per 100,000 women each year.
In Ghana, 29.3 out of every 100,000 women are diagnosed with cervical cancer and 27.6 out of every 100,000 women die from it every year.

Several factors contribute to these high numbers, including: 
Strong trust in traditional healers and mistrust of hospital care.
Cultural beliefs about the causes and treatment of cervical cancer.
Limited access to HPV vaccine.
Low awareness of cervical cancer and its symptoms
Low screening uptake

sections.name: section-1-3
sections.title: Female Pelvic Anatomy and Physiology
sections.description: Learn about internal and external female reproductive anatomy.

learningCards.name: section-1-3card-1
learningCards.title: External Organs
learningCards.content: Includes the vulva, labia, clitoris, urethra, perineum, and Bartholin glands.

learningCards.name: section-1-3card-2
learningCards.title: Internal Organs
learningCards.content: Includes the uterus, bladder, ureters, and how they function in reproduction.

learningCards.name: section-1-3card-3
learningCards.title: Diagnostic Tools
learningCards.content: These organs are examined using a speculum or laparoscopy to detect abnormalities.

postTest.name: posttest-1
postTest.question: What virus is the main cause of cervical cancer?

title: HPV and Cervical Cancer Connection
description: Learn how HPV infection leads to cervical cancer and how it's transmitted.

learningCards.name: section-2-1card-1
learningCards.title: HPV Types
learningCards.content: Over 100 types of HPV exist. Some cause warts; some cause cancer.

learningCards.name: section-2-1card-2
learningCards.title: Transmission
learningCards.content: HPV is transmitted through skin-to-skin contact, especially sexual.

learningCards.name: section-2-1card-3
learningCards.title: Persistence
learningCards.content: Most HPV infections resolve, but persistent ones can cause cancer.

sections.name: section-2-2
sections.title: HPV and Cervical Cancer
sections.description: How persistent HPV leads to abnormal cell changes.

learningCards.name: section-2-2card-1
learningCards.title: Cell Changes
learningCards.content: HPV can cause cervical cells to change abnormally.

learningCards.name: section-2-2card-2
learningCards.title: Precancer and Cancer
learningCards.content: If not treated, changes can lead to cancer over 10-20 years.

learningCards.name: section-2-2card-3
learningCards.title: Screening Importance
learningCards.content: Screening detects cell changes early for better outcomes.

postTest.name: posttest-2
postTest.question: What is the main cause of cervical cancer?

title: Screening and Early Detection
description: Understand the types of cervical cancer screening and their importance.

sections.name: section-3-1
sections.title: Screening Methods
sections.description: Learn about VIA, Pap smear, and HPV tests.

learningCards.name: section-3-1card-1
learningCards.title: VIA
learningCards.content: Visual Inspection with Acetic Acid is quick and low-cost.

learningCards.name: section-3-1card-2
learningCards.title: Pap Smear
learningCards.content: Detects abnormal cells from the cervix.

learningCards.name: section-3-1card-3
learningCards.title: HPV DNA Test
learningCards.content: Detects high-risk HPV types in cervical cells.

sections.name: section-3-2
sections.title: Who Should Screen and When?
sections.description: Recommended age and frequency of screening.

learningCards.name: section-3-2card-1
learningCards.title: Eligibility
learningCards.content: Start screening at age 25 or earlier if at risk.

learningCards.name: section-3-2card-2
learningCards.title: Frequency
learningCards.content: Every 3-5 years depending on method used.

learningCards.name: section-3-2card-3
learningCards.title: Follow-up
learningCards.content: Abnormal results need follow-up and possible treatment.

postTest.name: posttest-3
postTest.question: Which test uses acetic acid to visualize abnormal areas?

title: Prevention Strategies
description: Explore how vaccines, lifestyle, and safe practices help prevent cervical cancer.

sections.name: section-4-1
sections.title: HPV Vaccination
sections.description: Why and when to get vaccinated.

learningCards.name: section-4-1card-1
learningCards.title: Vaccine Types
learningCards.content: Vaccines protect against high-risk HPV types.

learningCards.name: section-4-1card-2
learningCards.title: Timing
learningCards.content: Best given before sexual activity starts.

learningCards.name: section-4-1card-3
learningCards.title: Effectiveness
learningCards.content: Up to 90% protection from cervical cancer.

sections.name: section-4-2
sections.title: Healthy Lifestyle Choices
sections.description: What you can do beyond vaccination.

learningCards.name: section-4-2card-1
learningCards.title: No Smoking
learningCards.content: Smoking increases risk of cervical cancer.

learningCards.name: section-4-2card-2
learningCards.title: Safe Sex
learningCards.content: Use protection and limit number of partners.

learningCards.name: section-4-2card-3
learningCards.title: Nutrition
learningCards.content: A healthy immune system helps fight infections.

postTest.name: posttest-4
postTest.question: What’s the best time to get the HPV vaccine?

title: Treatment and Management
description: Understand the treatment options for cervical precancer and cancer.

learningCards.name: section-5-1card-1
learningCards.title: Cryotherapy
learningCards.content: Freezes abnormal cells to prevent cancer.

learningCards.name: section-5-1card-2
learningCards.title: Thermal Ablation
learningCards.content: Destroys abnormal tissue with heat.

learningCards.name: section-5-1card-3
learningCards.title: LEEP
learningCards.content: Removes abnormal tissue using electrical loop.

learningCards.name: section-5-2card-1
learningCards.title: Surgery
learningCards.content: Removes tumors or entire cervix/uterus.

learningCards.name: section-5-2card-2
learningCards.title: Radiotherapy
learningCards.content: Uses high-energy rays to kill cancer cells.

learningCards.name: section-5-2card-3
learningCards.title: Chemotherapy
learningCards.content: Drugs to destroy or slow cancer growth.

postTest.name: posttest-5
postTest.question: Which method is used to freeze abnormal cervical cells?

title: Community Health and Advocacy
description: Learn how education, policy, and advocacy support cervical cancer prevention.

learningCards.name: section-6-1card-1
learningCards.title: Myths and Facts
learningCards.content: Correct common misconceptions.

learningCards.name: section-6-1card-2
learningCards.title: Peer Education
learningCards.content: Train women to educate their peers.

learningCards.name: section-6-1card-3
learningCards.title: Mass Campaigns
learningCards.content: Use radio, schools, and churches.

learningCards.name: section-6-2card-1
learningCards.title: Policy Support
learningCards.content: Push for national vaccination programs.

learningCards.name: section-6-2card-2
learningCards.title: Funding
learningCards.content: Ensure government and NGO funding.

learningCards.name: section-6-2card-3
learningCards.title: Equity
learningCards.content: Make prevention available to all women.

postTest.name: posttest-6
postTest.question: Which approach helps train individuals to educate their peers?
